title: mark ruffalo thor ragnarok leak live stream premiere marvel graham norton show
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Actor has become somewhat notorious for his accidental leaking&nbspof Marvel spoilersMark Ruffalo has revealed how Marvel reacted after his now-legendary Facebook Live leak of the premiere of&nbspThor: Ragnarok.&nbspThe actor appeared on&nbspThe Graham Norton Show&nbspwhere he discussed his new film,&nbspDark Waters,&nbspbut also his now-notorious habit of accidentally leaking film spoilers.&nbspBack in 2017, Ruffalo was attending the&nbspThor premiere when he took part in a backstage Facebook Live broadcast to fans before the film began, under instructions from the film’s publicity team.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesUnfortunately, he didn’t turn off the livestream before sitting down to watch the movie, and ended up broadcasting the first 20 minutes of the film to thousands of people.&nbspCreated with Sketch.Marvel films – ranked worst to best Show all 23Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.23. Iron Man 2 barely holds together. Rather than act as a straight sequel to the surprisingly successful Iron Man, Marvel Studios decided to overstuff the film with universe-building references (Black Widow, Nick Fury and SHIELD’s Agent Coulson all make appearances) and two-dimensional villains (played by Sam Rockwell and Mickey Rourke). The result is a film without any direction that serves as a Trojan horse set-up for the Avengers.22. When the Thor franchise lost its director Kenneth Branagh between the first and second films, it also had to kiss goodbye to the Shakespearean theatrics that had lent it a sense of goofy charm. Directed by Game of Thrones’s Alan Taylor, The Dark World prioritises its VFX effects above all else. It’s a dull affair: Christopher Eccleston’s Malekith is (by far) Marvel’s worst villain, being a pile of prosthetics with zero personality, while Chris Hemsworth’s Thor completes one of the most unrealistic London Tube journeys in all of cinematic history.21. Edward Norton’s version of the smashing Hulk often gets forgotten by Marvel fans – and for good reason. Whereas Mark Ruffalo’s bumbling interpretation of the character has a gravitational charm, Norton’s moping monster is void of any charisma. With Liv Tyler phoning in her performance as love interest, Betty Ross, the film falls emotionally flat and serves only as a by-the-numbers origins story.423 Avengers: Age of Ultron20. Just in case we’d forgotten that the Disney corporation is an all-consuming titan that owns half of Hollywood, the sequel to 2012’s Avengers decided to sneak in a little corporate synergy: when Iron Man accidentally creates a sentient robot (voiced by James Spader) who decides the earth’s only salvation is through the destruction of humanity, he announces his grim plans with accompaniment of a little citation of the classic “I’ve Got No Strings” from 1940’s Pinocchio. It’s a moment that exemplifies how Ultron feels like a cold, calculated operation from Marvel Studios. It’s merely tick list of obligations to move us on to the next chapter of the MCU.19. Although Kenneth Branagh’s introductory outing for Marvel’s God of Thunder fared perfectly well on release, it’s suffered massively from the MCU’s dramatic sense of progression over the years. Certainly, Tom Hiddleston’s Loki is a strong, well-crafted character right out of the gate, and his plot against his adoptive father (Anthony Hopkins) is delightfully heightened. Yet, it arguably took until Thor: Ragnarok for Chris Hemsworth’s hero to develop much sense of character beyond the initial “fish out of water” trope.18. A self-centred wealthy white man ventures to a distant land and realises his superhero potential – sound familiar? That’s because Doctor Strange and Iron Man are basically the same story, except one uses magic and the other explosives. Benedict Cumberbatch’s Marveldebut impresses with kaleidoscope visuals but lacks the heart of Robert Downey Jr’s hero, leading to a film that wastes the talents of both Tilda Swinton and Mads Mikkelsen. 723 s of the Galaxy Vol 217. The first s of the Galaxy was a risky Star Wars-inspired romp through space, following a bunch of a-holes who form an unlikely familiar bond. For the second film, James Gunn decided to turn everything up to 11, cramming half a dozen interweaving storylines, leading to Chris Pratt’s gaunt Star Lord getting side-lined. The sequel did, however, introduce the now beloved line “I’m Mary Poppins, y’all”, shouted by Yondu as he gracefully falls from the sky. A wonderfully comedic moment in a film that misses on another half-dozen punches.16. Marvel’s first crossover film was an unparalleled cinematic event – one that arguably changed Hollywood filmmaking forever, now that every major studio seems to be attempting the “shared universe” approach to franchises. Although the MCU has refined the template since, The Avengers still established the focus on humour, character, and heart that would come to define the success story of Marvel Studios. It’s a blockbuster that feels large on all fronts, delivering thrills not only in the “Battle of New York” finale, but in the creation of a team of characters that feel perfectly balanced and complementary.15. Despite Captain America: Civil War (AKA Avengers 2.5) featuring Iron Man, Black Widow, and Ant-Man (as well as introducing Black Panther and Spider-Man), the film remains first and foremost about Captain America. And that’s perhaps why the stuffed blockbuster works – were it not for a central focus, Civil War could have fallen into the trappings of other Marvel sequels in being too convoluted. The Russo Brothers also direct one of the best actions scenes in Marvel history so far, the airport scene, which looks as if it leapt straight out of a comic book.1023 Ant-Man and the Wasp14. While the first Ant Man was a mirror image of its star Paul Rudd, essentially delivering a studio comedy dressed in dex, the second found a new trick up its sleeve in the form of Evangeline Lilly’s Hope van Dyne – a smart, capable female hero who didn’t simply exist to serve as a caretaker for the male characters.13. What comes after the end? It’s the question that was hanging over the Marvel Cinematic Universe ever since the release of Avengers: Endgame was sold to us as the ultimate, cumulative chapter in a series of 22 interconnected films. And yet, while Far From Home is distinctly mid-level Marvel fare, there’s a lot to be said for the fact it isn’t crushed under the weight of its own ambitions. It feels comfortably like the end of a chapter, the beginning of a new one, an epilogue, and a palate cleanser all at once. It also works perfectly well as a film about Spider-Man.12. Ant-Man should not have worked as a film. Just look at the title! Ridiculous to think a movie about a man with ant powers should work – let alone be a blockbuster success and part of the biggest cinematic universe going. Yet, despite production problems (Edgar Wright was initially meant to helm the film), Peyton Reed directs this hilarious heist film with aplomb, taking the Marvel world a little less seriously than others. 11. Marvel redefined cinematic narratives once more in 2018, creating a single culmination to a decade’s worth of films. While it plays as total nonsense to anyone who’s a newcomer to the franchise (if that’s possible), it was, for fans, an unmatched emotional release. The Russo brothers faced the monumental task of making each crossover – from the s of the Galaxy to the kingdom of Wakanda – work in a way that feels natural, while also ushering the MCU’s biggest villain, Thanos, into centre stage. Epic both in its sense of scale and stakes, Infinity War also stages one of the most memorable finales in blockbuster history.10. With or without the beard, Steve Rogers aka Captain America has now become the brooding centre of the Avengers, but there was once a time when he was all about the old-fashioned heroics. Director Joe Johnston stayed true to the film’s 1940s setting in a film that embraces that pulpiness of early comic book history, as Steve punches Nazis and romances military officer Peggy Carter (Hayley Atwell), although her character is thankfully never relegated to the role of damsel in distress.9. Despite centring on a super-powered American nationalist, the Captain America trilogy has the most consistent quality in the MCU. Its crowning moment comes with The Winter Soldier – an adrenaline-fuelled conspiracy thriller that features a spectacular twist and provokes questions regarding modern day surveillance. However, given The Russo Brothers root the rest of the movie in realism, the bombastic CGI-heavy ending is a little ridiculous. 8. Brie Larson gives a superpowered performance as Carol Danvers, the actor playing a hero that's both relatable and aspirational, strong but vulnerable. While Captain Marvel may not revolutionise the studio’s formula, the superhero's debut outing provides a platform to show off her Thanos-annihilating powers.  Thanks to a smart script, it also offers some of the very best character development in the MCU.7. Tom Holland’s incarnation swings past Andrew Garfield’s version, thanks to the film’s lower-stakes high school story allowing for intimate moments with the character. Along with including some great comic performances (Jacob Batalon as Ned stands out), Michael Keaton’s Vulture makes for a terrifying villain, and the twist is superbly done.6. While isive among Marvel fans, Shane Black’s superhero outing – with the writerdirector’s sharp, stinging dialogue – brings Tony Stark's story arc to an end (or what should have been its end) with humour and heart aplenty. As Robert Downey Jr’s genius, billionaire philanthropist deals with PTSD and struggles with his robotic creations, we see an actor giving his all. While Civil War and the Avengers films dragged him back into action, fingers are crossed Avengers: Endgame will give the character a similar emotionally satisfying send-off.5. It’s a film that’s hard to place within the MCU canon, simply because the majority of its emotional pay-offs only work due to the groundwork laid by over a decade of filmmaking. Avengers: Endgame is less about inidual storytelling and so much more about the collective experience of cinema itself. This exists to be consumed in the dark, surrounded by loved ones, as  you all cheer, gasp, and cry in unison. The fan service at work may, at times, feel a little outrageous in just how bold it feels, but Endgame earns the right to indulge. This, above all, is a celebration of these movies and their impact on the world. 4. Completely transforming the Thor franchise in a single, effortless move, director Taika Waititi injected new energy into the MCU. Ragnarok is perfectly balanced both as a standard Marvel movie, with all the right heroics and world-building intact, and as a work belonging exclusively to Waititi, filled with the humour and charm he’d previously displayed in What We Do in the Shadows and Hunt for the Wilderpeople. By finding a way to incorporate inidual voices into its massive franchise machine, Marvel found the secret to true long-term success.3. Where it all started. Iron Man subverted expectations by not only reintroducing Robert Downey Jr to the world, but by showing that a relatively unknown B-character could be at the centre of a blockbuster. Other cinematic universes fail because they attempt to introduce too much (a mistake made in Iron Man 2). The first Iron Man, though, had a self-contained story that only hinted at a bigger world – a world that would eventually become a multi-billion-dollar franchise. 2223 s of the Galaxy 2. Blasting the Marvel universe into space for an adventure with a truly ragtag group of heroes, including both a talking racoon and a sentient tree-creature, s of the Galaxy is arguably the biggest risk the franchise ever took. And it paid off in spectacular fashion, with director James Gunn giving the superhero genre a light coat of B-movie glee. It also transformed Parks and Recreation star Chris Pratt into the major box office draw he is today.1. In the strife between Chadwick Boseman’s T’Challa, the ruler of Wakanda, and Michael B Jordan’s Killmonger, he provided a nuanced, layered commentary on colonialism and black identity. It’s a film that triumphs both within its genre, bringing new perspectives to the superhero story, and outside of it, satisfying purely as a piece of narrative drama.23. Iron Man 2 barely holds together. Rather than act as a straight sequel to the surprisingly successful Iron Man, Marvel Studios decided to overstuff the film with universe-building references (Black Widow, Nick Fury and SHIELD’s Agent Coulson all make appearances) and two-dimensional villains (played by Sam Rockwell and Mickey Rourke). The result is a film without any direction that serves as a Trojan horse set-up for the Avengers.22. When the Thor franchise lost its director Kenneth Branagh between the first and second films, it also had to kiss goodbye to the Shakespearean theatrics that had lent it a sense of goofy charm. Directed by Game of Thrones’s Alan Taylor, The Dark World prioritises its VFX effects above all else. It’s a dull affair: Christopher Eccleston’s Malekith is (by far) Marvel’s worst villain, being a pile of prosthetics with zero personality, while Chris Hemsworth’s Thor completes one of the most unrealistic London Tube journeys in all of cinematic history.21. Edward Norton’s version of the smashing Hulk often gets forgotten by Marvel fans – and for good reason. Whereas Mark Ruffalo’s bumbling interpretation of the character has a gravitational charm, Norton’s moping monster is void of any charisma. With Liv Tyler phoning in her performance as love interest, Betty Ross, the film falls emotionally flat and serves only as a by-the-numbers origins story.423 Avengers: Age of Ultron20. Just in case we’d forgotten that the Disney corporation is an all-consuming titan that owns half of Hollywood, the sequel to 2012’s Avengers decided to sneak in a little corporate synergy: when Iron Man accidentally creates a sentient robot (voiced by James Spader) who decides the earth’s only salvation is through the destruction of humanity, he announces his grim plans with accompaniment of a little citation of the classic “I’ve Got No Strings” from 1940’s Pinocchio. It’s a moment that exemplifies how Ultron feels like a cold, calculated operation from Marvel Studios. It’s merely tick list of obligations to move us on to the next chapter of the MCU.19. Although Kenneth Branagh’s introductory outing for Marvel’s God of Thunder fared perfectly well on release, it’s suffered massively from the MCU’s dramatic sense of progression over the years. Certainly, Tom Hiddleston’s Loki is a strong, well-crafted character right out of the gate, and his plot against his adoptive father (Anthony Hopkins) is delightfully heightened. Yet, it arguably took until Thor: Ragnarok for Chris Hemsworth’s hero to develop much sense of character beyond the initial “fish out of water” trope.18. A self-centred wealthy white man ventures to a distant land and realises his superhero potential – sound familiar? That’s because Doctor Strange and Iron Man are basically the same story, except one uses magic and the other explosives. Benedict Cumberbatch’s Marveldebut impresses with kaleidoscope visuals but lacks the heart of Robert Downey Jr’s hero, leading to a film that wastes the talents of both Tilda Swinton and Mads Mikkelsen. 723 s of the Galaxy Vol 217. The first s of the Galaxy was a risky Star Wars-inspired romp through space, following a bunch of a-holes who form an unlikely familiar bond. For the second film, James Gunn decided to turn everything up to 11, cramming half a dozen interweaving storylines, leading to Chris Pratt’s gaunt Star Lord getting side-lined. The sequel did, however, introduce the now beloved line “I’m Mary Poppins, y’all”, shouted by Yondu as he gracefully falls from the sky. A wonderfully comedic moment in a film that misses on another half-dozen punches.16. Marvel’s first crossover film was an unparalleled cinematic event – one that arguably changed Hollywood filmmaking forever, now that every major studio seems to be attempting the “shared universe” approach to franchises. Although the MCU has refined the template since, The Avengers still established the focus on humour, character, and heart that would come to define the success story of Marvel Studios. It’s a blockbuster that feels large on all fronts, delivering thrills not only in the “Battle of New York” finale, but in the creation of a team of characters that feel perfectly balanced and complementary.15. Despite Captain America: Civil War (AKA Avengers 2.5) featuring Iron Man, Black Widow, and Ant-Man (as well as introducing Black Panther and Spider-Man), the film remains first and foremost about Captain America. And that’s perhaps why the stuffed blockbuster works – were it not for a central focus, Civil War could have fallen into the trappings of other Marvel sequels in being too convoluted. The Russo Brothers also direct one of the best actions scenes in Marvel history so far, the airport scene, which looks as if it leapt straight out of a comic book.1023 Ant-Man and the Wasp14. While the first Ant Man was a mirror image of its star Paul Rudd, essentially delivering a studio comedy dressed in dex, the second found a new trick up its sleeve in the form of Evangeline Lilly’s Hope van Dyne – a smart, capable female hero who didn’t simply exist to serve as a caretaker for the male characters.13. What comes after the end? It’s the question that was hanging over the Marvel Cinematic Universe ever since the release of Avengers: Endgame was sold to us as the ultimate, cumulative chapter in a series of 22 interconnected films. And yet, while Far From Home is distinctly mid-level Marvel fare, there’s a lot to be said for the fact it isn’t crushed under the weight of its own ambitions. It feels comfortably like the end of a chapter, the beginning of a new one, an epilogue, and a palate cleanser all at once. It also works perfectly well as a film about Spider-Man.12. Ant-Man should not have worked as a film. Just look at the title! Ridiculous to think a movie about a man with ant powers should work – let alone be a blockbuster success and part of the biggest cinematic universe going. Yet, despite production problems (Edgar Wright was initially meant to helm the film), Peyton Reed directs this hilarious heist film with aplomb, taking the Marvel world a little less seriously than others. 11. The Russo brothers faced the monumental task of making each crossover – from the s of the Galaxy to the kingdom of Wakanda – work in a way that feels natural, while also ushering the MCU’s biggest villain, Thanos, into centre stage. Director Joe Johnston stayed true to the film’s 1940s setting in a film that embraces that pulpiness of early comic book history, as Steve punches Nazis and romances military officer Peggy Carter (Hayley Atwell), although her character is thankfully never relegated to the role of damsel in distress.9. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'It's the first time a lunar sample has been studied like this,' says researcherA new technique could provide major insights into the Moon's surface, the scientists behind it have said.The approach – which should allow researchers to find entirely new breakthroughs in pieces of lunar rock that are nearly 50 years old – involves analysing the rocks at the most minute level, in the hope of learning about the Moon.It could also help future astronauts who Nasa hopes can live on the Moon's surface in a lunar base, by allowing them to find important materials in the ground.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesWhen the last astronauts arrived on the Moon in 1972, they brought back important samples, like those who went before them. They were to be the last pieces of the lunar surface to come back to Earth, since humanity has not been back in the nearly 50 years since.That means that those remaining samples are especially precious since they are limited and can not be easily replaced. They can also be profoundly illuminating, offering us our only chance to get close to rock taken from a whole separate world.Created with Sketch.Nasa's groundbreaking decade of space exploration: In pictures Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Mystic Mountain, a pillar of gas and dust standing at three-light-years tall, bursting with jets of gas flom fledgling stars buried within, was captured by Nasa's Hubble Space Telelscope in February 2010The first ever selfie taken on an alien planet, captured by Nasa's Curiosity Rover in the early days of its mission to explore Mars in 2012Death of a star: This image from Nasa's Chandra X-ray telescope shows the supernova of Tycho, a star in our Milky Way galaxyArrokoth, the most distant object ever explored, pictured here on 1 January 2019 by a camera on Nasa's New Horizons spaceraft at a distance of 4.1 billion miles from EarthAn image of the Large Magellanic Cloud galaxy seen in infrared light by the Herschel Space Observatory in January 2012. It's the first time a lunar sample has been studied like this. We're using a technique many geologists haven't even heard of.Scientists to make air out of lunar dust amid plans to live on MoonAs researchers make use of the new technique, they expect to find a vast set of new information about the lunar surface.We can apply this technique to samples no one has studied, Philipp Heck, a curator at the Field Museum, associate professor at the University of Chicago, and co-author of the paper, adds. You're almost guaranteed to find something new or unexpected.This technique has such high sensitivity and resolution, you find things you wouldn't find otherwise and only use up a small bit of the sample.The technique is called atom probe tomography, and involves incredibly precise manipulation of inidual grains. It has previously been used in industrial processes – but the new breakthrough has come in turning it for the first time to lunar samples.It works something like nanocarpentry, said Professor Heck: like a carpenter shapes wood, we do it at the nanoscale to minerals.The sample is placed inside a special probe and then shot with a laser that knocks off inidual atoms, which then fall onto a special plate. Researchers can examine those elements by timing how long they take to hit the detector – since heavier ones take longer – and so the type of atom can be worked out.It has already helped researchers see the weathering and materials that can be found inside the lunar soil. That in turn could help future astronauts as they move to live on the Moon, since they could survive by taking resources out of that dust.The researchers now hope they can get hold of samples from elsewhere on the Moon, and elsewhere in space, to allow them to better understand the makeup of the worlds that surround us. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘I was brought up here. I don’t know anything else. I made one mistake in life, and it feels like I tried to kill the Queen’A man who has been in the UK since the age of 11 and has a British baby is set to be deported on a charter flight to Jamaica within days.Reshawn Davis, 30, was detained last Friday and told he would be removed to Jamaica on 11 February – on the second charter flight to travel to the country since the Windrush scandal two years ago.He is being removed from the country on the basis that he was convicted for robbery 10 years ago under the now-unlawful “joint enterprise” rule –&nbspfor which he spent two months in prison.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe Jamaican national, who lives with his British wife&nbspand six-month-old daughter in northwest London and has not committed any crime since his conviction, said the thought of being ripped from his family and returning to a country he has not been to for 20 years terrified him.&nbspUp to 50 other Jamaican nationals have been detained in recent weeks and are set to be deported on the same charter flight, which has been the subject of mounting controversy.A draft copy of the Windrush Lessons Learned report, leaked to the media on Thursday, said ministers should consider ending the practice of deporting people who arrived in the UK as children – prompting calls for ministers to halt the removal of iniduals like Mr Davis until it is published.Created with Sketch.UK news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Activists surround a wooden trojan horse in the courtyard of the British Museum in London. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘I can’t get hold of my solicitor – the only chance of getting out of here... It feels like I’m losing my mind’Ministers have admitted a mobile phone outage at removal centres has prevented people from accessing legal&nbspservices to challenge their deportation, days before a charter flight is set to leave the UK.The Home Office has been forced to admit it has known about the issue affecting detainees’ mobile phone signals in detention centres near Heathrow airport since 13 January, but took 23 days to begin providing detainees with working sim&nbspcards – during which it pressed ahead with charter flights to Ghana, Nigeria and France.Campaigners accused the government of removing people from the country without giving them their lawful right to legal advice and assistance during&nbspthe “crucial window” leading up to the removal flights.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesPeople who are due to be deported on a charter flight to Jamaica on Tuesday told The Independent that as a result of the outage, they had struggled to communicate with their solicitors and send them relevant documents to challenge their removals.Mobile phones provided by the Home Office at the outset of detention are the principal means by which detainees are able to access legal assistance, contact their solicitors and stay in touch with their families.Government told to review deportations days before charter flightEchard Bepart-Woollett, 27, who came to Britain when he was eight&nbspand has two British children, said he had been struggling to communicate with his solicitor since the Home Office issued him with deportation orders last week.“I can’t get hold of my solicitor – the only chance of getting out of here. It’s getting mad. It feels like I’m losing my mind. It’s like all communication has been shut down. Everyone is trying to get hold of their solicitor to see what’s going on,” said the Jamaican national.“If they don’t get the paperwork, I can’t go to court, I can’t fight. It’s black and white. You need everything documented and proven, and if I can’t get that out, then I’m f***ed.”Mr Bepart-Woollett’s solicitor, Marina Khan of Duncan Lewis Solicitors, said her client had a strong case&nbspto remain in Britain but that the mobile outages had meant filing submissions to challenge his deportation has taken much longer than normal.“We were trying to contact him every day since he instructed us on 31 January, and it took us until 6 February&nbspto formally take details instructions from him. It’s been awful. His partner was stressing out,” she said.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. I couldn’t send it during office hours because I didn’t receive it in time. The delay was unreasonable.“It’s caused a lot of undue stress and frustration for our client. He’s been totally deprived of contacting his legal representatives and unable to access legal justice and advice from us.”MPs Nadia Whittome and Dawn Butler raise the issue of people on next week’s deportation flight to JamaicaAnother detainee, Reshawn Davis, 30, who came to the UK at the age of 11 and has a British six-month-old baby,&nbspsaid the signal issues were “extremely frustrating”.“People are telling me they’re trying to call me and I don’t see the call. My phone just doesn’t ring. I haven’t spoken to my solicitor directly at all because of the signal. It’s been a huge added stress. I don’t know what’s going on,” he said.“It’s stopping me talking to my family as well. My daughter knows my voice. If I say something over the phone, she’s thinking Daddy’s home. I say her name and she looks up for me. But this signal is preventing me from talking to her.”People facing imminent removal from the UK are entitled to notice periods ranging from three to five days during which it is, by law, vital that they are able to access legal advice and assistance, for example to assess the merits of challenging their removal.Windrush victims given additional two years to apply for compensation‘Home Office is destroying their lives’: Father-of-two to be deportedGovernment told to review deportations days before charter flightBella Sankey, director of Detention Action, which has launched a legal challenge against the Home Office over its alleged failure to provide effective access to legal advice to detainees, said: “An eleventh-hour issuing of sim cards may not be sufficient for those seeking to challenge their removal on Tuesday’s flight. Not to mention the impact on those that have been removed while the signal has been down.&nbsp“This is a partial victory for access to justice but there are many unanswered questions and our legal challenge will proceed.”It comes after a&nbspleaked draft of the&nbspWindrush&nbspLessons Learned&nbspreview stated that ministers should consider ending the practice of deporting people who arrived in the UK as children, prompting calls for the Home Office to put&nbspdeportation flight on hold until the review is published.The Home Office has been approached for comment.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: jeremy corbyn labour election defeat inquiry next leader
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Exclusive: Damning report&nbspexpected on the eve of&nbspannouncement of&nbspnext party leaderJeremy Corbyn is to snub a formal inquest into Labour’s disastrous performance in the general election.The Labour leader is not taking part in the probe into what went wrong at the polls, The Independent&nbspunderstands, which is due to examine the root causes behind&nbspthe party’s&nbspworst electoral&nbspdefeat since before the Second World War.Headed up by former leader Ed Miliband, the inquiry is expected to report that Labour was hopelessly outmatched by the Tories in its digital campaign, while&nbspactivists on the ground were repeatedly confronted with concern about Mr Corbyn, insiders said.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe damning report is expected to be released on the eve of the announcement of the next Labour leader, with a source saying: “We want it to be the first thing in the new leader’s in-tray.”The news comes ahead of the final stage of&nbspthe race to succeed Mr Corbyn, with candidates facing a Valentine’s Day&nbspdeadline to win sufficient support from affiliated trade unions and local parties.Labour told to avoid ‘self-pity’ over historic election defeatShadow cabinet members Sir Keir Starmer and Rebecca Long-Bailey, and Wigan MP Lisa Nandy have already passed the threshold to get onto the ballot paper but Emily Thornberry, the shadow foreign secretary, is struggling to make up ground.While the leadership contest is dominating the headlines, a group called Labour Together, made up of people different wings of the party, is trawling through views from members, ousted MPs and Labour supporters on what went wrong in 2019.Insiders said it was clear that the Tories had significantly upped their online game since the 2017 election, which meant the party benefited from people sharing its message organically, rather than through paid advertisements.Mr Corbyn’s leadership also repeatedly featured on the doorstep, with newspaper reports on his associations with Sinn Fein during IRA bombing campaigns appearing to resonate more strongly than in the previous election.Burgon pledges rule change so Labour cannot back wars without voteLong-Bailey calls for scrapping Heathrow expansion amid climate crisis‘Get on with it’: Thornberry tells members to nominate her for leaderInsiders said the report will show that voters wanted “a hand up,&nbspnot a hand out” and pointed to strategic mistakes by the party leadership.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.The former director of public prosecutions undoubtedly has announced that he is standing for the leadership. He is highly-regarded by both left-wingers and centrists in the party. As Labour’s shadow Brexit secretary, he played a key role in the party’s eventual backing of a second referendum. A key ally of the current left-wing leadership of the party, the Salford &amp Eccles MP is viewed in some quarters as the natural successor to Mr Corbyn and describes herself as a “proud socialist”. Highly regarded by the shadow chancellor, John McDonnell. She won also won plaudits for her performance filling in for Corbyn both at prime minister’s questions and during the general election debates.Corbyn’s constituency neighbour and friend, Emily Thornberry, has been critical of the party’s Brexit stance, but has remained loyal to the leadership and has represented the Labour Party on various overseas visits. Shadow education secretary Angela Rayner has joined the contest for deputy leadership of the party. title: coronavirus news live china uk virus symptoms hong kong wuhan latest today
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Follow here for the latest developmentsThe coronavirus is poised to become more deadly than SARS, as the global death toll climbed&nbspto 724.Hong Kong imposed quarantine rules on travellers from mainland China, where the virus claimed 86 lives on Friday – more than any other day since the outbreak began.Meanwhile, a British honeymooner was transferred to a Japanese hospital from the Diamond Princess cruise liner, where nearly 3,700 passengers and crew, including his wife, remain stranded onboard in the port of Yokohama.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesPlease allow a moment for the live blog to load.Wuhan residents 'dragged from homes'Five new cases in France are all Britons, minister saysBritish family of four hospitalised in MajorcaVirus claims 86 lives in mainland ChinaBrighton shopkeeper introduces&nbspmask and glove policyA shop owner in Brighton has asked customers to wear face masks and plastic gloves in the wake of nearby coronavirus diagnoses. &nbspChinese shop owner Lai Chen Zhang, 30, put a sign outside Yung Feng Oriental Food Store on London Road explaining the new policy. Disposable gloves are available at the front of the shop. &nbspI want to protect my customers and make them feel comfortable,''Queen offers condolences to China via Prince AndrewChina's state media outlets have welcomed a message from Queen Elizabeth, who expressed her sympathies to the nation and said she was praying&nbsp for the speedy control and victory over the virus.&nbspThe condolences were passed on by Prince Andrew to the Chinese ambassador. It is unclear if the visit was in a personal or professional capacity, given the duke of York's commitment to step back from public life over his relationship with billionaire paedophile Jeffrey Epstein.&nbspThe Queen also offered New Years greetings to President Xi Jinping and his citizens,Infected woman gives birth to healthy child - Chinese state media&nbspA coronavirus-infected woman has given birth to a health child, according to Chinese state media.&nbspThe infant was born in the east of the country in Zhejiang province, and is being monitored in intensive care ahead of further testing, the communist party's Xinhua news agency reports.&nbspIt comes days after doctors warned it may be possible to transmit the illness from mother to child in utero after a newborn was observed to have contracted the virus.World Health Organisation team to head to ChinaThe head of a World Health Organization-led international team investigating the&nbspcoronavirus&nbspoutbreak will leave for China on Monday or Tuesday, WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said.&nbspThe international health official, asked whether the team would include experts from the US Centers for Disease Control (CDC), told a press conference on Saturday: We hope so.It comes after the New York Times reported the CDC had offered to help in the region but had been ignored for weeks.Coronavirus: how serious are disease outbreaks onboard cruise ships?With thousands of passengers aboard&nbspDiamond Princess&nbspin&nbspquarantine&nbspin Japan, the cruise industry has brought in a severe and unprecedented measure to try to prevent further outbreaks.&nbspBut the incident has drawn attention to the risks on&nbspcruise ships.Here's the Independent's Simon Calder&nbspon the risks and rights when it comes to the coronavirus at sea.&nbspOutbreak 'probably not much worse than particularly bad influenza year', infectious diseases expert saysAt the moment the mortality rate is looking at about two per cent, which is a little bit more than we would see for influenza, but I suspect that mortality rate will drop as we increasingly find less severe cases,&nbspDr Paul Hunter told&nbspThe Independent's travel correspondent Simon Calder.So in terms of the severity of the disease, it's probably not that much worse than a particularly bad influenza year.  Dr Hunter explains the chances of catching the coronavirus on a flight are not zero, but extremely low.Here's more on the wartime measures introduced in Wuhan, amid reports of hazmat suit-clad officials going door-to-door and forcing people suspected of being infected with the virus&nbspinto quarantine.The stricter steps were announced by&nbspSun Chunlan as she visited the virus-stricken city on Thursday, announcing:&nbsp“There must be no deserters, or they will be nailed to the pillar of historical shame forever.”&nbspThe Associated Press&nbsphas this country-by-country update on the outbreak's spread:China: 722 deaths and 34,546 confirmed cases on the mainland, mainly in Hubei province.Hong Kong: 25 cases, including one death.Macau: 10Japan: 90Singapore: 40Thailand: 32South Korea: 24Taiwan: 16Malaysia: 16Australia: 14Germany: 14Vietnam: 13United States: 12. Separately, one US&nbspcitizen died in ChinaFrance: 11United Arab Emirates: 7Canada: 6Philippines: 3 cases, including 1 deathUnited Kingdom: 3India: 3Italy: 3Russia: 2Belgium: 1Nepal: 1Sri Lanka: 1Sweden: 1Spain: 1Cambodia: 1Finland: 1Singapore has confirmed seven new cases of coronavirus, Reuters reports, bringing the total number of cases in the country to 40.The British national found to be infected with the virus in Brighton is said to have travelled to Singapore, as is the initial case believed to be at the root of the five cases confirmed in France today.&nbspAccording to the French director general of health, authorities in Singapore are investigating a three-day business meeting that took place in a hotel from 20 January, at which 94 foreign nationals were present.'We're definitely not prepared': Africa braces for new virusThe Associated Press&nbsphas the following report from Zambia, where workers on the ground and other experts warn the country is not prepared to deal with an outbreak:&nbspAt a Chinese-run hospital in Zambia, some employees watched as people who recently returned from China showed up with coughs but were not placed in isolation. A doctor tending to those patients has stopped coming to work, and health workers have been ordered not to speak publicly about the new virus that has killed hundreds around the world.The virus has yet to be confirmed in Africa, but global health authorities are increasingly worried about the threat to the continent where an estimated 1 million Chinese now live, as some health workers on the ground warn they are not ready to handle an outbreak.Countries are racing to take precautions as hundreds of travelers arrive from China every day. Safeguards include stronger surveillance at ports of entry and improved quarantine and testing measures across Africa, home to 1.2 billion people and some of the world's weakest systems for detecting and treating disease.But the effort has been complicated by a critical shortage of testing kits and numerous illnesses that display symptoms similar to the flu-like virus.The problem is, even if it's mild, it can paralyse the whole community, said Dr&nbspMichel Yao, emergency operations manager in Africa for the World Health Organisation.We're definitely not prepared. If we had a couple of cases, it would spread very quickly, physiotherapist Fundi Sinkala said. We're doing the best we can with what resources we have.Three British children being examined for virus in France attended local schoolsTwo British children, and the nine-year-old known to have contracted the virus, are among 11 people under the watch of authorities after coming into close contact with those found to be suffering from the virus.All three children attended local schools, an official told BFM TV.Two people are believed to become the first foreign nationals to die from the virus in Wuhan.A Japanese man and American man&nbspdied in the city, although it has not been confirmed whether the former had contracted the virus, despite suffering from severe pneumonia.“We offer our sincerest condolences to the family on their loss,” a US embassy spokesperson in Beijing said. “Out of respect for the family’s privacy, we have no further comment.”86 people were reported to have died from the virus in mainland China on Friday&nbsp– the deadliest day of the outbreak so far.Two schools are to temporarily close in the French resort where five Britons were found to be suffering with the coronavirus, a regional health official says.The child among the group, who the official confirmed is nine years old, is believed to have spent time in local schools.​Amid an ongoing investigation, authorities are checking who the British nationals came into contact with.A second evacuation flight bringing back Singaporeans and their family members from virus-hit Wuhan in China is expected to arrive on Sunday morning.The city-state evacuated 92 Singaporeans from Wuhan last Thursday, some of whom have since been confirmed as infected. Authorities said they had to leave some passengers behind who were showing symptoms.A flight carrying medical supplies and diagnostic test kits, departed this afternoon for Wuhan, the country's foreign ministry said. Appropriate quarantine arrangements have been made for all of the returnees, it added.Two Britons infected with the virus are thought to have contracted it while in Singapore.The country's authorities are&nbspinvestigating a three-day business meeting held in&nbspa hotel from 20 January&nbspbetween&nbsp94 foreign nationals, France's&nbspdirector general of health, Jerome Salomon, said.Government tells Brighton pupil's parents to ‘self-isolate’ child for 14 days&nbspPublic Health England has told the parents of a pupil in Brighton suburb to self-isolate their child, who reportedly came into contact with a man found to be suffering with the virus on Thursday.Parents whose children attend Portslade Academy were emailed yesterday to inform them of the development by head teacher Mark Poston, Brighton and Hove News reported.“We are working in collaboration with and being guided by the local authority and Public Health England to ensure that we at PACA are acting consistently with the right medical advice, Mr Poston wrote.“Today we have been contacted by a parent of a student at PACA who was contacted by Public Health England as part of their investigation concerning the confirmed case that was reported in the press yesterday.“We have been informed by the parent that they have been advised by Public Health England to self-isolate their child at home for 14 days. If at any point the child is found to be symptomatic we will be notified.Fear more harmful than virus, Singapore PM says after raising alert levelPrime minister Lee Hsien Loong appealed for the public to remain calm, after the alert update&nbspprompted&nbspresidents to clear out supermarket shelves of rice, noodles and toilet paper.Singapore raised its response to orange - the same as during the 2003 Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) outbreak, which indicates the virus is severe and passes easily between persons.There is no need to panic. We are not locking down the city or confining everybody to stay at home,the PM&nbspsaid on Saturday. We have ample supplies, so there is no need to stock up with instant noodles, tinned food, or toilet paper, as some people did yesterday.UK to donate £5m to World Health OrganisationThe Department for International Development said the sum would help the WHO prevent the spread of the virus in developing countries,&nbspby supporting them to rapidly identify and care for patients with symptoms.Additional experts funded by UK aid will be deployed to the WHO to help coordinate the international response, the&nbspstatement said.This week, the UN health agency asked the international community for £560m to help their efforts to combat the virus.On Friday, the United States signalled it would donate $100m in foreign aid to help the response in China and other countries.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: tv licence bbc blame reputation
story: So the new Government consultation over decriminalising non-payment is long overdue.A compulsory tax made sense in . Punishing non-payers nowadays is absurd.The Beeb will fight all the way. But consider how it has trashed its once-proud reputation:Fundamentally it’s a dinosaur in the Netflix era and irrelevant to many, especially young people raised on YouTube.The Government must be bold. We need a much slimmer BBC to survive and focus on quality TV and radio.But the licence has had its day.BORIS Johnson can only lead the world on climate change with the public on his side and our economy in the front of his mind.The Government churns out random dates in the not-too-distant future by which it demands we all buy electric cars and replace our gas central heating.Yes, the UK is hosting a climate summit this year and it must be ambitious.But do the Tories have a clue about the cost to consumers and the economy  Michael Gove was suspiciously coy.This country is not governed by Greta Thunberg — nor the Marxist wreckers running Extinction Rebellion.The Tories must level with the public and ensure that our global warming efforts BOOST the economy instead of wrecking it.And they will be near-worthless anyway unless the world’s worst polluters, China in particular, follow the example Britain is already setting in slashing emissions.JIHADIST murderers and their supporters should be judged criminally insane and held indefinitely as long as they are a danger.Most villains recognise our civilisation’s definitions of right and wrong.IS do not. Their extreme version of Islam legitimises slaughtering innocent people.Anyone  randomly stabbing ­passers-by or encouraging it would probably be classed as insane and locked away forever. Why not jihadis  The fact they consider their motives rational and noble proves they have lost their minds.Lesser offenders may be deradicalised, though that is a long shot. Others should be kept without time limit in a secure unit, maybe built specically for them.If we treat these religious madmen like “ordinary” murderers — with a stretch in a normal prison — we will keep making the same disastrous mistakes. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ban disel giant leap in the dark
story: THE wheels are already coming off the Government’s electric car revolution.The lack of joined-up thinking is depressing.Only . per cent of new motors sold in the UK are electric. Which is not surprising when they are at least £, more than the petrol equivalent and most have woeful mileage ranges.Yet the Government, desperate to advertise its green credentials, blithely announces a ban on new petrol, diesel and even hybrid cars in just  years.But it’s not a concrete, costed plan . . . just a giant leap in the dark.How does it intend to totally re-equip Britain for roadside charging — or fund it while its multi-billion pound fuel duty income withers away to nothing How will people afford these cars unless prices plummet, which experts say is unlikely in the foreseeable future  And why is the Government poised to axe the subsidies that help us to buy We don’t in principle think taxpayers should fund anyone’s new motor. But why remove buyers’ sole financial incentive now, when the industry badly needs a jump-start The Government is hopping on a bandwagon without considering the consequences, like Labour  years ago when it urged everyone to buy diesels.Meanwhile councils are already brainlessly instigating city centre bans or fines on all but the tiny number of zero-emission vehicles currently on the road.Who can blame motorists for being confused and angry  Many will happily drive more eco-friendly cars once they are viable and affordable.But this is all stick and no carrot.BRITAIN should not be proudly flying our flag for Prince Andrew’s birthday. It is a grotesque gesture in the circumstances.Maybe his long, close friendship with Jeffrey Epstein — a jailed paedophile, pimp and sex trafficker of under-age girls — was entirely innocent.But he has still been sacked from Royal duties and accused of ignoring FBI demands to question him.Epstein’s victims are adamant Andrew mustto the US.What an insult to themTown Halls raise the Union Jack to honour him instead.WHEN it comes to helping the disabled, Boris Johnson can put his money where his mouth is right now.We are delighted to see the PM ask every Cabinet minister to find ways their department can contribute to his new National Disability Strategy.But there’s a £million black hole in funding for social care for families with disabled kids which Sajid Javid’s Budget on March  should fill. Our Give It Back campaign has highlighted it.Turn warm words into action, PM.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tension reporters no10 system snapped
story: As Sun readers know, there are important issues at the moment, from anti-terrorism laws, to HS, to post-Brexit Britain’s trading prospects. What is the future of the BBC  Should China build our telecoms network Seldom has the political news agenda been so packed. But what is the story gaining traction at Westminster  For the latest, let’s go straight to our correspondent outside  Downing Street - who, oh dear, is stomping away in protest like Dick Emery’s Honky Tonks, having just had a blazing row with Boris Johnson’s media strategist.Yes, the big story, crazily, is the stand-off between political journalists and the PM’s media advisers. The reporters, hardly the most delicate bunch of dahlias, are wailing that the Government is being beastly to them.In the blue corner we have Downing Street’s press officers who, in an unusual interpretation of the Trade Description Act, are refusing to speak to the Press. When newspapers write about themselves, readers are entitled to roll their eyes.Political news, like the mass-production of pork bangers, is a manufacturing process best conducted away from the view of consumers. Not unless you want to turn the whole country vegan.I’ve been in newspapers since the mid-s, much of the time at Westminster, and have met drunkards, liars, gropers, cheats — and that was just the religious-affairs writers. Don’t let’s pretend journalism or politics attracts innocent hayseeds. Which makes the over-reacting on both sides of the ide in recent days so ridiculous.Creative tension between reporters and politicians’ media handlers is a healthy thing, but the system has suddenly snapped. This follows a general election in which it sometimes felt as though the media, particularly broadcasters, niggled Boris Johnson more effectively than Jeremy Corbyn did.When Boris won a thumping majority, his aides may have thought: “Right, now we can exact revenge on our media tormentors.” If so, they are foolish and unprofessional.First, they started mucking about with the daily briefings to the Westminster press lobby, the club of accredited journalists who report on politics.Then, on Monday, they tried to bar some members of that lobby from a briefing by David Frost, Boris’s main adviser on the European trade negotiations. Some scribes were told they could attend, others were told they were barred.Downing Street claimed that the briefing was too specialised for general politics writers to appreciate. The reporters took a dferent view.They reckoned Downing Street strategist Dominic Cummings and his sidekick Lee Cain were trying to ide and rule, and to winnow out the journalistic troublemakers. In a rare moment of solidarity among hacks, the newshounds upped and left. Walkout!This squabble is now headline news. Urgent questions were raised in the Commons and many papers and broadcasters are protesting that the Government is trying to censor the free Press in a “sinister” way.They compare this tactic to Donald Trump’s denunciation of mainstream US media for spreading “fake news” . Sir Keir Starmer, would-be leader of the Labour Party, joined the outcry, siding with the journalists. We could have done without that slippery little bit of opportunism.The same Starmer boasted recently that he would refuse to talk to reporters from The Sun, presumably because this paper is not in his pocket.Attempts to neutralise awkward reporters are not exactly new. During the  election, as a scurvy political sketch writer, I was locked out of a Tony Blair campaign event in The Wrekin.Gordon Brown’s people stopped me attending a media event with the president of South Africa.Tory party cronies barred me from witnessing a leadership debate between David Cameron and David Davis in . In the last election, non-sympathetic journalists were not given access to Jeremy Corbyn’s battle bus. Mind you, we were lucky. As one Leftie reporter told me: “You couldn’t get on Corbyn’s bus but I couldn’t get OFF it!”Despite some of those historic precedents, the current “lobby war” is more problematic because it looks more concerted and because it comes at a time when traditional news sources are under challenge from the internet.Online news sites can be shady and unreliable. Traditional lobby journalists, for all their faults, are at least reasonably accountable.Both sides should cool it. The lobby should admit that its clique is unacceptably clubby for st-century politics. And Boris’s henchmen should drop the macho posturing. Why are they picking this fight at a time when the Government is so popular  Never a better time for it, they might say. They want to show who’s boss.You could compare their aggression to that of an inmate who on arrival in prison butts the first guy he meets in order to show other prisoners he’s a tough guy. In my experience, journalists respond badly to this approach.Look at the damage Tony Blair’s thuggish spokesman Alastair Campbell did to the government he served.It is not beyond the wit of ministers to palm favourable stories to selected journaliststhey so wish. But the central media unit at No should remember — as they have repeatedly told us — that they are “the people’s Government” and not merely the servants of Boris Johnson.Their juicy salaries come from the taxpayer and the taxpayer does not expect them to abuse their privileged position.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: new homes 30 per cent cheaper
story: Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick’s “First Homes” plan will take landowners’ profits to pay for a discount of  per cent.The move, aimed at the lower paid who are battling to save to buy a home, will lop an average of £, off the asking price of a typical home.And the discount will be locked in to the ­property’s price to ensure it is sold on at well below the usual asking price, to help the first-time buyers of the future.As well as locals, ­forces’ veterans will be prioritised for the house purchases along with front-line workers such as cops, nurses, prison officers and teachers.The plan, a Tory manesto promise, is the first in a major drive by Boris Johnson’s government to get more young people on the property ladder and solve Britain’s chronic housing crisis.Dubbing the plan “genuinely le-changing”, Mr Jenrick said: “Many who are seeking to buy their own home in their local areas have been forced out due to rising prices.“A proportion of new homes will be made available at a  per cent market discount, turning the dial on the dream of home ownership.”THE new “First Homes” plan could be a game-changer for young people priced out of owning property.We wouldn’t normally back a state scheme to carve off developers’ profits to subsidise homes.But the market has failed a generation, rapid action is needed and builders’ takings are vast.Soaring prices and Help To Buy sent their margins into orbit.The giants have squeezed out small rivals and release new builds slowly to keep prices up. Their bosses make mind-boggling salaries.It’s payback time.Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick’s imaginative plan will cut prices for local first-time buyers by a third —  a huge dference.But the Government must ensure hundreds of thousands of affordable homes get built this way.Previous over-hyped initiatives have produced derisory numbers.Long-term we need a bonfire of planning restrictions,  more developers able to compete and far more houses built.Campaigners warned the new homes must not come at the expense of losing new social housing.Polly Neate, boss of Shelter, said: “The country desperately needs more low-cost homes which are genuinely affordable to those people struggling at the sharp end of the housing crisis.“But, instead of offering a route to building additional low cost homes, this policy simply puts at risk the social homes currently being built.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: praise british coast people
story: But rarely in all the debate about what our future now holds do you hear about the wonders of our coastline — which, when you think we have more than , miles of it, doesn’t feel right.Presenting Our Coast with Mehreen Baig, I’ve seen just how beautul it is, and how many brilliant people live their lives there.They are a special breed of unsung heroes.It can be tough for sure, in places the rest of us used to holiday — places we profess to love, often without actually doing that much to nurture.There are challenges in many coastal communities, and they definitely need the money politicians of all stripes have promised them.But I’ve also been struck by how hard they’re working to turn things around themselves. There is often hope where we may first see ­dficulty. You just have to look a bit harder sometimes.In Portpatrick, at Scotland’s bottom left corner, the harbour had fallen into miserable disrepair. A plan was hatched to stop the rot.A local hero organised a share issue for locals to raise the money to buy the harbour and restore the buildings around it. The village now has its pecker up again and the future looks bright.It’s a similar story on Anglesey. At Halen Mon a thriving family business draws water out of the Menai Strait, harvests the salt and sells it all over the world.Near there I met a woman called Sian Sykes who cared about those waters so much she paddle-boarded  miles around Anglesey picking out the plastic.Asthat wasn’t enough, she then paddled the whole coast of Wales doing exactly the same.But my favourite character round there is no longer with us. On the very western tip of Holy Island off Anglesey’s west coast, there is the South Stack lighthouse. It’s been saving sailors from watery deaths since .A hundred years ago, John Jones was its keeper and it was his great granddaughter Denise Shaw who took me up to the top of it.Denise showed me a photograph of her great-grandad sporting a magnicent moustache the seagulls must have coveted for their nests.He was no loner, though. Denise remembers her mum saying old great-gramps was a bit of a ladies’ man.And what a chat-up line he had at his disposal: “Do you want to come back to my place to see how bright my light is ”All four of the areas we’ve looked at for this series of Our Coast are around the Irish Sea. I had a brilliant time at Belfast docks where I joined the harbour pilots, whose work astounded me.It’s their job to bring the giant ships safely into port.I sort of assumed they did this by chugging out to meet them, lighting up a sign saying, “follow me” and gently leading them to their berths.Far from it. Round the clock, all year round, whatever the weather, they race out several miles to pull up alongside these huge vessels.Incredibly, a rope ladder is dropped over the side for the pilots to clamber aboard, make their way to the bridge, take over the controls and steer these monsters into tight spaces on the docks.The ship I boarded with them, somewhat terried, was carrying grain from Romania.As my man took the helm I asked the Polish skipper which country had the best harbour pilots. “You do,” he said, with feeling.Back across the Irish Sea, in Formby, north of Liverpool, I met Mike McComb in the £million place he’s built himself a stone’s throw from the sea.He has more bedrooms, bathrooms and children than I could count .His fortune could have bought him a lavish home anywhere in the world. But it was up here, along the endless beach, that back in the day he and his mates would come on their bikes from their tiny homes in Bootle.So, he tells me as we stand on the beach, lashed by rain and wind, you can keep St Tropez or Malibu. This coast, his coast, is where he’ll stay.The sea seems to be a magnet for the most memorable people, from Grace the crane engineer in Belfast Docks who played rugby for Ireland in three rugby world cups, to Sandy the tattooed pagan near Stranraer who says the sea’s our mother, and the Bulgarian dissident I chanced upon sitting in a hot tub ­surveying Liverpool from the deck of the Queen Mary .My grandad used to tell me that when you put your toe in the sea you’re connected with the whole world.With that in mind, I’ve enjoyed many a paddle this summer reflecting on the power and history of what our island nation is all about.And I urge you to do it, too. After all, it’s pretty easy. Britain’s most landlocked place — Coton in the Elms in Derbyshire — is just  miles from the coast. So none of us is more than a couple of hours away from the sea.There’s never been a more relevant time to get out to the edges and see the soul of this country.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus uk china live
story: Coronavirus has now been confirmed in  countries, and took the lives of  people on Friday alone.The news comes as it was revealed five Brits had been struck down with the virus at a ski resort in France.Japan earlier announced its first national to die from the virus putting the global death toll just  behind the  fatalities recorded during the SARS epidemic of -.Follow our live blog below for all the latest updates...THE family of a Chinese citizen journalist who exposed the severity of coronavirus in Wuhan say they are #deeply worried# after he was reported missing.Chen Qiushi, who also works as a human rights lawyer, has not been heard from since pm local time on Thursday, with calls to his mobile going unanswered.He has not been seen or heard from since the death ofdoctor, Li Wenliang, who first raised the alarm at the outbreak of the coronavirus.Mr Qiushi became known as a citizen journalist, someone who doesnt work in the media who reports on social matters typically through social media.The number of global coronavirus cases could be ten times higher than official figures show, a leading British scientist has warned.Amid rising concern over the spread of the virus, experts said the vast majority of cases were likely to have been missed.And John Edmunds, a professor at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, said modelling showed there were ‘ten times more cases than have been reported – or even more’. title: orangutan hand save man snakes
story: The gentle creature appears to be leaning down and offering a helping hand to the man who had been in the muddy river searching for snakes - many of which pose a threat to primates.The striking pictures were taken in a conservation forest area in Borneo, where the endangered species are protected from hunters.Amateur photographer Anil Prabhakar, from Indonesia, had been out trekking with friends in the area while on safari, when he spotted the touching encounter taking place.He later found out that the unnamed man worked for the Borneo Orangutan Survival Foundation, a non-profit organisation aimed at protecting the endangered species.The worker, submerged up to his chest in the water, had been clearing away snakes from the area to help keep the orangutans safe before his inquisitive animal friend interrupted him.Mr Prabhakar revealed the worker actually ended up refusing the orangutans hand after the camera caught the incredible moment in a picture, because its a wild animal.He said: Someone told him there was a snake in the river. The warden went there and cleared the bushes.”An orangutan came to the banks and was watching what he was doing. He then came closer and gave his hand.”The warden just moved away. I asked him why later and he said, Its a wild animal, not one we are familiar with.”But they are to protect them.The Borneo Orangutan Survival Foundation is an Indonesian non-profit organisation founded in .It is “dedicated to the conservation of the Bornean orangutan and its habitat”, working in cooperation with local communities, the Indonesian Ministry of Forestry and international partner organisations.The foundation, which has  members of staff, is currently taking care of almost  orangutans.The website says: As one of our closest living relatives orangutans are highly intelligent, sentient beings.”They are an iconic species of Indonesia and an important umbrella species.By protecting orangutans in their natural habitat, a whole plethora of other flora and fauna are also protected. Protecting their forest habitat is as important to humans as much as it is to wildle.

title: jeremy corbyn wont give evidence at review into labour partys worst defeat in 85 years
story: The Labour boss is not giving evidence to the inquiry into what went wrong, which is expected to slam his woeful strategy.Party insiders said the report will find that voters were horried by Mr Corbyn’s alleged links with terrorists like the IRA.While it will also find that Labour “totally lost” the online election battle with the Tories, who managed to get their messages picked up widely on sites like Facebook.The devastating report is expected to be released on April  - the day before the winner of the Labour leadership battle is announced.A Labour source said: “We want it to be the first thing in the new leader’s in-tray”.The inquiry, led by Ed Miliband, is looking into why Labour suffered their worst defeat since .The team has been talking to former MPs who lost their seats, Labour frontbenchers, advisers and activists about where it all went wrong. But bizarrely, Mr Corbyn is not planning to speak to the body about the landslide defeat.One party insider said the report will show that voters were furious at Mr Corbyn and his allies for patronising them.The source said: “Voters wanted a hand up not a hand out by middle class do-gooders.“The defeat was a massive surprise for many activists in groups like Momentum. They didn’t see it coming.“There is a lot of anger from the left over why we did not adopt a more defensive strategy.”The inquiry will warn that Labour desperately needs to rebuild in Scotland, where the now only have one MP, to stand a chance of winning power ever again.The source said: “We can’t win without Scotland. We would have to win Jacob Rees-Mogg’s seat of North East Somerset to get a majority without Scotland.”

story: The mint-flavoured pink pill could be on sale in two years at £ a pop.It could help millions of women, especially those in their s and s, researchers say.The breakthrough comes  years after Viagra was patented for use in erectile dys.Dutch researcher Prof Eric Claassen said: “A lot of women are really unhappy. There is an enormous unmet need.“These women are not seeking help because they want sex every day but because they want a healthy sex le.”The pill is set to become the first to boost female libido to be licensed in Europe.The prescription-only drug is taken ½ hours before sex, and comes in two versions.Lybrido, containing testosterone and sildenafil — the active ingredient in Viagra — works on the brain and body to put women in the mood for sex.Lybridos, a combination of testosterone and buspirone, is aimed at women who feel inhibited between the sheets.Women take a saliva test to work out which to take.The pills have been tested on  women who filled in an online diary after sex.In one trial users enjoyed two extra sex sessions, and one more orgasm a month.Adriaan Tuiten, of maker Emotional Brain, hopes the treatment will “break taboos” and allow “women to take charge of their bodies”. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kirk douglas was the one and only spartacus and he had balls of steel
story: When Kirk came into the world, the Battle of the Somme was still raging and Sir Ernest Shackleton — my own hero — was fighting to save his men on a doomed Antarctic expedition.At , Kirk’s death was not unexpected. But it saddened us all because it felt like this incredible human being would go on for ever.He headed the Douglas dynasty with a zest for le that put the rest of us to shame and was one of our final links to Hollywood’s golden age.Long before actors ostentatiously wore their hearts on their sleeves and made self-aggrandising speeches about the latest trendy cause, Kirk determinedly set out to do the right thing, regardless of any impact on his career.In the Fties, at the height of the Cold War, he stood up to a paranoid US government that considered anyone to the left of Genghis Khan a Soviet sympathiser.The McCarthy witchhunts ruined careers and wrecked lives, but Kirk dug in his heels and hired blacklisted writer Dalton Trumbo to work on Spartacus, which would become Kirk’s most famous movie.That took balls of steel.Kirk gave millions to charity and was a US Goodwill Ambassador, receiving the Presidential Medal of Freedom from Jimmy Carter in .He experienced heartache with the death of his son Eric from an overdose and the jailing of grandson Cameron for drug offences.But even a near-fatal helicopter crash and a stroke couldn’t defeat Kirk.His son Michael — a superstar in his own right, of course — told me last year his dad worked out almost every day with a personal trainer and remained as sharp as a tack, keeping the whole extended family on their toes.I was lucky enough to interview Kirk back in my days with TV-am.The Beeb would fly them over from LA and put them up in a posh hotel.All we could offer was a hearty breakfast, plus the chance to talk about themselves and their new project for as long as they liked.There were no pesky managers and PRs to go through.Bette Davis, Burt Lancaster, Lauren Bacall and Sammy Davis Jnr all popped into our studio at the crack of sparrows, staying for the duration of the show.Kirk was here in , promoting Dance With The Devil, a racy novel that bore a passing resemblance to his extraordinary le story.After his Jewish parents escaped persecution in Russia, Kirk was born and raised in a poor area of New York.It is a real rags-to-riches tale. His dad actually worked as a rag-and-bone man.Kirk never forgot where he came from, which is perhaps why he became a champion for justice and a fairer society.He was a delight that morning and even laughed when the crew declared, “I’m Spartacus”, one after another in his honour — though he must have seen it done hundreds of times before.He was a also a much-loved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather.The Douglas clan will be in mourning but they can celebrate a le well lived.This weekend, I am on a Kirk Douglas marathon, starting with Paths Of Glory, before The Bad And The Beautul, Ace In The Hole, The Vikings, Lust For Le and, of course, Spartacus.Tomorrow’s Oscars will rightly honour him. We won’t see his like again.I WAS honoured to host The Millies this week.It is a wonderful event run by The Sun to salute our Armed Forces and give us all a chance to say a huge thank you.As always, there were astonishing stories of bravery, courage and self-sacrice.And as always, our lovely winners told me they were nothing special, just doing their job.I honestly don’t think they realise just how remarkable they are, or how much we owe them.One of my highlights was seeing -year-old Private Fin Doherty collect his award for inspiring others.Fin was just six when his paratrooper big brother JJ was killed in action in Afghanistan.Fin was determined to follow in JJ’s footsteps to honour his brother’s memory, and join the Parachute Regiment.He has been an outstanding addition and, in an emotional ceremony, was presented with JJ’s beret in December.Their mum Joyce admits she struggled with Fin’s decision to sign up, following the death of her eldest son.But she knew it was all Fin wanted – and she is so very proud of him.We honestly don’t deserve such an inspirational young man. But thank the Lord we have him on our side.NOTHING has changed. Phillip Schofield is exactly the same person he was before he felt the time was right to tell the world he’s gay.He’s still a loving father and husband and will still host his TV shows with consummate professionalism and skill.As Phillip said himself, you never know what people are struggling with every day and, for him, it was time to be honest with himself and everyone .I’m really glad that he has made the decision and very proud of him, although obviously it can’t have been easy.There’s been lots of tears, sleepless nights and a great deal of soul-searching. I hope he now finds peace of mind.He is a very lucky man to have a family and friends who love him very much and just want him to be happy.He also has a loyal fan base who love watching him on This Morning and that won’t change. Why would it Of course, he can expect a small number of bigots and homophobes to spew out hateful bile, but they are to be pitied and ignored.Those carping about why he took so long also need to shut up.People should be allowed to come out when it feels the right time for them.Phillip began his career at a time when being openly gay in a TV presenting role was just not an option.Thank goodness things have changed and he can be open now – and know that the overwhelmingly vast majority of us wish him and his family nothing but the very best.I was really touched by what he said about interviewing brave people on This Morning, and realising that he had to be just like them and tell his truth.Love comes in many dferent forms.Phillip and his we Stephanie adore each other and that won’t change. Again, why on earth would it At the end of his statement Phillip urged us all to be kind, especially to his family, and I hope we all take those words on board.Let’s wish them all the best and let them get on with their lives.WHAT a furore over a bare shoulder. Actress-turned-MP Tracy Brabin didn’t deserve the vitriol about her outfit but it WAS distracting.It’s unfortunate because Tracy was making important points about journalists being shut out of No  briefings – a move that makes my blood run cold and threatens Press freedom. Sadly, no one was really listening.Tracy told me she had been at a music event and didn’t expect to be back in the House. She is bemused by all the fuss.How those in public le dress should not detract from their message, be it a female MP in a low-cut top or mini-skirt, or a man wearing a gaudy tie or tight trousers.Our MPs are not known for their style and rarely make headlines for their fashion sense.I am very happy for them to keep it that way.WELL, that was a rather ill-advised memo to send, reminding local councils to fly the Union Flag on February  as a “celebration” of Prince Andrew’s birthday.I had no idea this was a “thing” and that Andrew was on a list of VIPs whose birthdays are marked with a flag waving on the roof of our town halls, instead of just cake and prosecco like the rest of us.Unsurprisingly, this ludicrous edict has caused much disgruntlement.As we know, Andrew has been booted out of The Firm by his own mum after that disastrous TV interview delving into his friendship with the American paedophile Jeffrey Epstein.Then there is the ongoing scandal over whether or not Andrew will be interviewed by the FBI as part of its investigations into child trafficking allegations against Epstein.It is all very sordid and murky. Surely even his nearest and dearest would agree this is not the time for official celebrations.He is no longer a working royal and has no place on that list.Time to lower the flags for good. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
